text:
well, the athmospere in the game is perfect. a large cool world, with many unknown creatures, mazing graphics (for the time it came out), and awesome music. it all fits together to perfection.
copple this with great gameplay, tight controls, innovative puzzles, (kind of) co-op action, humor and well designed characters with good voice actors.... well go figure

author: sonideromex

text: I liked Jade's design, perhaps that picture doesn't do the in-game character model justice. I liked her clothing and hair style, gives her an edge which fits nicely with the semi-futuristic world, and remember that the games graphical style isn't a ultra realstic one, it's stylized with slightly exaggerated features. If you want to know what a more realistic looking Jade would look like, try Alex Vance from Half-Life 2.
author: Joshua Birch

text:
well yes, you do have a point Wolf, but come on, you have to agree that Jade's character design could have been MUCH better.
And you're using extremes as an example. DOA and RR are examples where girls are portrayed as being perfect.... I'm not asking for that, just asking for an acceptable design...which Jade does NOT have.

text: Sigma I'm hoping that was a joke, if it isn't thats a terrible attitude to have and you're they reason we have trash like Dead or Alive Xtreme Beach Volleyball and Rumble Roses. I hate seeing these women in games with impossible bodies and perfect skin as it just plays to the stereotype that gaming is only for teenage boys. I see gaming as an artform and a new medium of storytelling that whilst its still in its infancy, has real potential. We need more female leads like Jade and less T&A.
